items.title: Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation slowdown suppresses Atlantic Niño variability
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 06 November 2025

Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation slowdown suppresses Atlantic Niño variability
                    Pedro Freire-Souza1, Gabriel M. Pontes2,3,4, Laurie Menviel2,3 & …Ilana Wainer1 Show authors

npj Climate and Atmospheric Science

volume 8, Article number: 355 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Atmospheric scienceClimate and Earth system modellingClimate changeClimate-change impactsOcean sciencesPhysical oceanography

AbstractfThe Atlantic Niño is the dominant mode of interannual variability in the Tropical Atlantic with significant impacts on local and remote climate patterns. Despite recent advances in understanding the mechanisms leading to weakened Atlantic Niño variability, its primary causes remain unknown. Here, we use an Earth System Model to show that the strength of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) modulates air-sea feedbacks in the equatorial Atlantic through both atmospheric and oceanic teleconnections. The combination of a southward shift of the Intertropical Convergence Zone and the propagation of oceanic downwelling Kelvin waves due to an AMOC weakening, generated in the subpolar North Atlantic, deepens the eastern thermocline and weakens the equatorial trade winds, leading to a decoupling in air-sea feedbacks. Finally, we show that adding the effect of meltwater in future projections reduces the upwelling feedback strength by 60 ± 6% in 2100, with potential changes in the Atlantic Niño-driven rainfall.

IntroductionThe Atlantic Niño is the primary mode of variability in the tropical Atlantic Ocean1,2,3, significantly affecting not only tropical rainfall, including the Sahel and Amazon basins precipitation4,5, but also remote extratropical regions6 and tropical inter-basin processes7,8,9,10. Atlantic Niño events result from anomalous exchange of heat and momentum between the ocean and the overlying atmosphere. Positive sea surface temperature (SST) anomalies in the central and eastern equatorial Atlantic alter the sea level pressure and weaken the easterly trade winds. Anomalous winds perturb the thermocline below, generating downwelling oceanic Kelvin waves that travel eastward along the Equator and deepen the eastern equatorial thermocline. A deepened thermocline increases the heat content within the mixed layer, further enhancing the initial positive SST anomalies1,2,3.Recent studies have identified a significant persistent decrease in the Atlantic Niño variability since the 1970’s11,12,13, and this variability is projected to further weaken under global warming14. The Atlantic Niño decline has been mostly attributed to a decoupling between surface and subsurface temperature variations due to a persistent deeper thermocline11,12,14, but also with contributions from weakened ocean-atmosphere coupling15 and basin-wide warming related to climate change12,13. Weakened air-sea coupling in the equatorial Atlantic is caused by weaker and more stable winds that reduce the effectiveness of wind anomalies in promoting changes in the thermocline15. Rising SSTs due to enhanced CO2 concentrations in the atmosphere increase the heat flux from the ocean to the atmosphere, thus damping the initial positive SST anomalies13.Although changes in Atlantic Niño feedbacks can be directly affected by global warming, these could also be driven or amplified by teleconnection processes16,17. The equatorial Atlantic can be influenced by the variability of the Pacific and Indian Oceans on inter-annual to decadal timescales through tropical inter-basin interactions. First, El Niño events, characterized by positive SST anomalies in the central-eastern Pacific, displace the Atlantic Walker cell eastwards, resulting in weaker trade winds over the Atlantic basin18. As such, persistent enhanced El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) activity can possibly lead to weaker Atlantic Niño variability. Secondly, warm anomalies in the tropical Indian Ocean intensify the Atlantic equatorial winds through a tropical baroclinic response19, thus possibly favouring enhanced Atlantic Niño variability. However, the recent period of reduced ENSO activity20,21 and the CO2-driven Indian Ocean warming are inconsistent with a decreased Atlantic Niño variability through tropical basin interaction mechanisms. Lastly, the intensity of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC), which is the major circulation system in the Atlantic Ocean, has been shown to affect SST variability in the Indian22 and Pacific23 Oceans. In the Atlantic Ocean, a weakening of the AMOC leads to significant warming in the Tropical South Atlantic due to a deepening of the thermocline24,25. The AMOC weakening also decreases the southeastern trade winds over the Atlantic basin17, which could impact the Atlantic Niño variability. Despite being an ongoing topic of research, there is increasing proxy-data and observational evidence suggesting that the AMOC has weakened since the mid-20th century25,26,27, possibly consistent with reduced Atlantic Niño activity since the 1970’s. However, the response of equatorial SST variability to AMOC changes is yet to be elucidated. In this context, we first perform idealized subpolar North Atlantic freshwater hosing experiments with an Earth System Model to investigate AMOC-driven teleconnection processes that could reduce the Atlantic Niño variability. We then use our results to evaluate the sensitivity of the Atlantic Niño variability to an AMOC weakening under global warming.ResultsAtlantic Niño response to an AMOC weakeningTo investigate the impact of an AMOC weakening on Atlantic Niño variability and dynamics, we perform numerical simulations with the Australian Community Climate and Earth System Simulator version 1.5 (ACCESS-ESM1.5)25,28. The ACCESS-ESM1.5 model is skilful in simulating both AMOC intensity and Equatorial Atlantic mean state and feedbacks, which allows a realistic assessment of the linkage between the two phenomena. Firstly, the model simulates the AMOC at a strength of 19 Sv (Fig. 1a) in the pre-industrial scenario, in agreement with direct AMOC estimates of the mid-twentieth century (20.1 Sv from ref. 29). Furthermore, the model captures the observed equatorial Atlantic mean state during the peak season of the Atlantic Niño (June-July-August (JJA)), including the negative zonal SST gradient and thermocline slope (Fig. 2d)15. Lastly, the ACCESS-ESM1.5 simulates the relationship between coupled processes in the equatorial Atlantic in the pre-industrial climate (Fig. 2a–c), important for Atlantic Niño development and known as Bjerkenes Feedbacks, with correlation coefficients greater than 0.7 (Supplementary Table S1), and simulating feedback strengths in close agreement with observations (Fig. 2a–c)14,30.Fig. 1: Structural and variability changes in Atlantic Niño due to an AMOC collapse.a Temporal evolution of the AMOC strength, defined as the annual-mean maximum Atlantic Ocean meridional streamfunction (Sv) at 26∘N in the AMOC-on and AMOC-off experiments. b Atlantic Niño index, defined as sea surface temperature anomalies (SSTa) in the eastern equatorial Atlantic (ATL3 region; 3∘S-3∘N, 20∘W-0∘) in June-July-August. Shading indicates the long-term (second-degree polynomial) variability trend (21-years running standard deviation) of the Atlantic Niño index. c, d Atlantic Niño index regressed onto SSTa in AMOC-on and AMOC-off, respectively e, f Atlantic Niño impact over precipitation, wind, and sea-level pressure fields in AMOC-on (d) and AMOC-off experiments (e). Shading indicates the Atlantic Ninõ index regressed against precipitation anomalies (\({{mm.day}^{-1}} ^{\circ }{\text{C}}^{-1}\)), contour lines represent the index regressed against sea level pressure anomalies (hPa ∘C−1), and vectors represent the index projected onto wind anomalies \((m.{\text{s}{}^{-1}}^{\circ }{\text{C}}^{-1})\). Stippling in panels c–f represent regions in which the linear regression coefficients are statistically significant at the 95% level based on 1000-sample bootstrapping. c, e and d, f were computed using the AMOC-on (−100 to 0 years) and AMOC-off (400 to 500 years) time slices, respectively. A mask over the continents was applied to the pressure data to facilitate visualization.Full size imageFig. 2: Temporal evolution of the Bjerknes feedbacks and Equatorial Atlantic Climatology.Components of the Bjerknes Feedbacks estimated through linear regression of a eastern equatorial Atlantic (ATL3; 3∘S-3∘N, 20∘W-0∘) SST anomalies onto western equatorial Atlantic (ATL4; 3∘S-3∘N, 40∘W-20∘W) zonal wind stress anomalies during JJA, b equatorial thermocline slope anomalies during JJA onto ATL4 zonal wind stress anomalies during March-April-May and c SST anomalies in ATL3 during JJA onto thermocline depth anomalies in ATL3. The equatorial thermocline slope is computed as the difference in the mean depth of thermocline, defined as the 20 °C isotherm, between ATL3 and ATL4. Colours indicate four different periods: AMOC-on (blue), between 50 and 150 years after the addition of freshwater (green), between 150 and 250 years after the addition of freshwater (yellow), and during the AMOC-off period (red). α indicates the regression coefficient. d Trends in upper-ocean temperature averaged between 3∘S and 3∘N in the first 100 years of the hosing experiment. Horizontal lines indicate the depth of tthe hermocline for the AMOC-on (blue) and AMOC-off (red) periods. Temporal evolution of annual mean e equatorial thermocline slope, f thermocline depth in ATL3, g sea level pressure in the North Atlantic Subtropical High region (35∘N-40∘N, 60∘W-20∘W) and h zonal wind stress in ATL4.Full size imageWe first perform an idealized AMOC shutdown experiment by adding 0.4 Sv of freshwater in the subpolar North Atlantic under constant pre-industrial background climate conditions (Methods). This idealized forcing was implemented to provide a robust assessment of the impact of AMOC strength on the global climate. Given the high internal variability of the equatorial Atlantic, this forcing provides a high signal-to-noise ratio. In this water hosing simulation, the AMOC takes approximately 170 years to decline from an intensity of 19 Sv to below 5 Sv (Fig. 1a). This period of rapid weakening is followed by a slower reduction, ultimately ending up in a new equilibrium state, when the AMOC strength stabilizes at around 3 Sv (hereafter referred to as AMOC-off; red line in Fig. 1a). This simulation is compared to the pre-industrial control run31 (hereafter referred as AMOC-on).The collapse of the AMOC significantly reduces the northward Atlantic Ocean heat transport, leading to accumulation of heat in the Southern Hemisphere and a deficit in the Northern Hemisphere, thereby reversing the inter-hemispheric temperature contrast (Supplementary Fig. 1). In response to this, the atmospheric circulation in the Northern Hemisphere intensifies in an attempt to export the excess energy out of the Southern Hemisphere. In the equatorial Atlantic, these global changes drive a southward shift of the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) and a weakening the equatorial southeasterly trade winds (Supplementary Fig. 1).The freshwater hosing induces a gradual weakening (Fig. 1b and Supplementary Fig. 2) of the Atlantic Niño, with a 21% weakening between years 50 and 100, and ultimately reaching a 37% weakening between years 400 and 500 (Supplementary Fig. 2) compared to the unperturbed state (AMOC-on). This weakening is accompanied by a significant change in the spatial pattern of the Atlantic Niño SST anomalies (Fig. 1c, d). Under a collapsed AMOC, the warming core shrinks towards the central equatorial Atlantic, with cooling observed in the southeastern Atlantic (Fig. 1d). The new spatial pattern results in substantially different wind and precipitation responses (Fig. 1e, f). The classic positive Atlantic Niño fingerprint causes negative sea-level pressure anomalies in the eastern equatorial Atlantic, weakening the southeasterly winds and shifting the ITCZ southward. This results in increased precipitation along the equator, including the Amazon and Congo basins (Fig. 1e). On the other hand, the anomalous surface pattern under a collapsed AMOC drives higher sea level pressure in the southeastern South Atlantic (Fig. 1f), strengthening the southeasterlies. This leads to drier conditions in south equatorial and tropical western Africa, while increasing precipitation in northeastern Brazil. The new pattern shows a diminished impact of the Atlantic Niño on eastern Amazon rainfall. It is important noting that the tropical Atlantic is one of the remote regions most strongly impacted by an AMOC collapse. As such, large changes in the mean state under this scenario (Supplementary Fig. 1) can possibly alter the ocean-atmosphere feedbacks at play in the equatorial Atlantic mode, as we discuss in the following section.Weakened ocean-atmosphere coupling due to an AMOC collapseTo investigate the mechanisms behind changes in the variability of the Atlantic Niño when the AMOC weakens and collapses, we evaluate the three main ocean-atmosphere coupling feedbacks (Bjerknes Feedbacks), related to the development of Atlantic Niño events30. First, the zonal advection feedback (BF1) measures the amplification of the response of eastern equatorial SST anomalies to anomalous zonal wind stress in the western equatorial Atlantic. Secondly, the thermocline feedback (BF2) identifies the intensity of the response of the thermocline slope due to changes in zonal wind stress. Finally, the upwelling feedback (BF3) measures the effect of local changes in the eastern Atlantic thermocline depth on SST anomalies (Methods).To understand how the Bjerknes feedbacks in the equatorial Atlantic are changing due to the weakening of the AMOC, we split the North Atlantic hosing experiment into 4 periods: before the addition of freshwater (P0; AMOC-on; blue in Fig. 2); between 50 and 150 years after the addition of freshwater (P1; green); between 150 and 250 years after the addition of freshwater (P2; yellow); and during the AMOC-off period (P3; red). Results indicate that its weakening during the transient AMOC slow-down (P1 and P2) is mostly driven by a weakened upwelling feedback (BF3), and with significant contribution from the zonal advective feedback (BF1). During P1 and P2, BF3 weakens by approximately 60% and 120%, respectively (Fig. 2c), while the zonal advective feedback (BF1) weakens by 40% and 92%, respectively (Fig. 2a). On the other hand, the thermocline feedback (BF2; Fig. 2b) increases by up to 20% during P1 and P2. Finally, under a collapsed AMOC (P3), the reduced Atlantic Niño variability is primarily caused by the reduction in the upwelling feedback (BF3), followed by the zonal advective feedback (BF1). The thermocline feedback (BF2) reduces by only 30%, indicating that the reduced variability is primarily driven by BF1 and BF3.In understanding how an AMOC weakening can affect the Bjerknes feedbacks in the equatorial Atlantic, we initially evaluate the temporal evolution of the main features of the coupled tropical climate. First, trends in mixed-layer temperatures (Fig. 2d) indicate a more pronounced warming in the subsurface layer of the eastern equatorial Atlantic, resulting in a deeper thermocline (Fig. 2f) and consequently a weaker influence on surface waters (e.g., weakened BF3). Furthermore, the western equatorial Atlantic experiences a subsurface cooling trend, resulting in a shallower thermocline. Together, these changes reverse the thermocline slope as the AMOC collapses (Fig. 2e).Here, we identify two teleconnection processes from the subarctic North Atlantic that contribute to reversing the equatorial thermocline slope. First, an atmospheric teleconnection is triggered by reduced northward oceanic heat transport (OHT). To compensate for the heat deficit in the Northern Hemisphere, the atmospheric circulation intensifies and expands southwards to export heat from the Southern Hemisphere32,33 (Supplementary Fig. 1). This process is also identified in our simulations by strengthened atmospheric subtropical circulation in the North Atlantic (Fig. 2g) and a southward shift of the ITCZ (Supplementary Fig. 3a). This meridional atmospheric teleconnection drives the weakening of the equatorial winds (Fig. 2h and Supplementary Fig. 3b,c), which ultimately act on decreasing the thermocline slope.Secondly, an oceanic teleconnection is triggered by displaced isopycnals in the subarctic region, due to freshwater input and reduced deep ocean convection. Downwelling Kelvin waves propagate along the western boundary and reach the equatorial Atlantic25,34,35,36. In the ACCESS-ESM1.5 model, we assess the propagation of coastal Kelvin waves through their impact on the baroclinicity of the mean flow in the western boundary currents of the North Atlantic - namely, the Gulf Stream and the North Brazil Current (see Methods, Supplementary Fig. 4). As baroclinic Kelvin waves propagate due to an increased density gradient towards the boundary, the offshore large-scale wind-driven pressure gradient weakens. Thus weakening the boundary currents through the thermal-wind balance34,37,38,39,40. An analysis of the western boundary currents reveals that Kelvin wave propagation reduces the zonal density gradients in both the Gulf Stream and the North Brazil Current, consistent with the expected response from thermal wind balance (Supplementary Fig. 4; Methods). Noting that in addition to being affected by Kelvin waves25 under an AMOC weakening scenario, the intensity of the boundary currents can also be affected by freshwater advection through interior pathways41.In the equatorial Atlantic, Kelvin waves also contribute to the initial deepening of the mean equatorial thermocline. The suppressed eastern upwelling leads to intense rates of warming in the eastern equatorial Atlantic. This reinforces the reduced surface east-west SST gradient and, consequently, weakening of the trade winds, thus triggering the reversal of the thermocline slope. The deepening of the eastern equatorial thermocline suppresses the upwelling feedback (BF3) under AMOC weakening. It is important to note that while Kelvin waves play a significant role in reducing the zonal SST gradient along the equator, it is the interaction with atmospheric processes that ultimately shapes the final thermocline structure.As a result of these teleconnections mechanisms, when the AMOC collapses, there is a reversal in the direction of the trade winds (Fig. 2h), in the thermocline slope (Fig. 2e), and in the zonal SST gradient (Supplementary Fig. 1a). These changes result in increased heat content in the eastern Atlantic mixed-layer (Fig. 2d). Under this new configuration of the equatorial Atlantic, Atlantic Niños are likely triggered from the east (Fig. 1f), where heat anomalies propagate from east-to-west. In this scenario, easterly wind anomalies in the eastern Atlantic reactivate the upwelling on the African coast, displacing the eastern warm waters toward the central Atlantic, as indicated by a reversed relationship between eastern upwelling and ATL3 SSTs (BF3 red line in Fig. 2c). This mechanism is also consistent with the reversal of BF1 (red line in Fig. 2a), where positive SST anomalies in ATL3 are now related to easterly wind anomalies, further contributing to the advection of positive SST anomalies from east to west. These results indicate that the more centred equatorial Atlantic mode driven by an AMOC shutdown operates through substantially different ocean-atmosphere feedbacks. The absence of a positive upwelling feedback when the AMOC collapses suggests that the more centred pattern could be associated with reduced amplitude.Changes in atmospheric meridional heat transport also affect the mean state and variability of the tropical Pacific and Indian oceans that can in turn affect the Atlantic Ocean16. To investigate the possible role of the Pacific ocean in the Atlantic Niño weakening, we evaluate changes in the intensity of the equatorial trade winds and ENSO amplitude, as persistent increased ENSO activity can lead to weaker Atlantic trades, thus reducing Atlantic Niño activity15. We find that the Pacific trades (160∘E-90∘W; 5∘S-5∘N) intensify by 17% and ENSO weakens by 18% (Niño34 standard deviation change) in the AMOC-off period. Both changes are consistent with a Pacific mean state change towards a more La Niña-like state42. As multi-year La Niña events tend to trigger Atlantic Niño events43, changes in the Pacific Ocean do not contribute to the weakened Atlantic Niño. The tropical Indian Ocean (50∘E-90∘E; 5∘S-5∘N) has a small, not significant, annual mean cooling response (-0.23∘C) in our AMOC-off experiment, thus likely playing a minor role in equatorial Atlantic changes16.Impacts of a weakened AMOC in historical and future scenariosSimilarly to the results of the idealized AMOC weakening experiments presented above, the upwelling feedback (BF3) has been shown to be the major contributor to the decreased Atlantic Niño variability seen since the 1970’s11,12,44. Furthermore, based on SST and Sea Surface Salinity (SSS) trends in the Atlantic, the AMOC has been suggested to be weakening since the mid-20th century25,45,46,47. As such, to evaluate the possible role of the ongoing and future AMOC weakening on the recent and projected decrease in Atlantic Niño variability, we analyse two ensembles of simulations performed with the ACCESS-ESM1.5 model that span 1850 to 2100 (Supplementary Fig. 5). The first ensemble consists of 10 members of the historical and high-emissions scenario (ssp585) performed under the CMIP6 protocol48 (referred as access-cmip). The second ensemble consists of 8 members under the same protocol but with the addition of freshwater to the subartic Atlantic to represent enhanced meltwater input from the Greenland ice sheet and Arctic glaciers, process not included in the CMIP6 protocol48,49 (referred as access-fw). The freshwater forcing in the access-fw simulation is ~ 0.05 Sv between 1960 and 2020, and then includes decadal increments of 0.025 Sv under the ssp585 scenario (Supplementary Fig. 5a). This forcing was designed to capture the AMOC weakening trend as suggested by observations and was scaled by the projected Greenland temperature increase for the 21st century25. The difference between access-cmip and acccess-fw thus reflects the influence of a hypothetical meltwater input from the Greenland ice sheet melt and, consequently, the impact of a more pronounced AMOC weakening on the Atlantic Niño.The access-fw ensemble simulates a statistically significant decrease (at the 95% level) in the Atlantic Niño variability from 1985 to 2020 relative to the reference period 1850-1890 (ATL3: −9 ± 8% in the 21-years running standard deviation; Supplementary Fig. 6). The Atlantic Niño decrease in access-fw is driven by a significant weakening (at the 95% level) of the upwelling feedback (Fig. 3c), consistent with observations11,12. On the other hand, access-cmip simulations show no statistically significant changes in both Atlantic Niño variability (−7 ± 13%; Supplementary Fig. 6) and in the three main components of the Bjerknes Feedback (Fig. 3a–c).Fig. 3: Future changes in Atlantic Niño dynamics due to global warming and meltwater input.Components of the Bjerknes Feedbacks (see Methods): a zonal advection feedback (BF1), b thermocline feedback (BF2), and c upwelling feedback (BF3). The y-axis shows the percentage change relative to the reference period (1850-1890) for two periods: (1) historical from 1985 to 2020 and (2) future from 2080-2099. Coloured boxes represent the 10th-90th percentile range, while whiskers indicate the full ensemble range. access-cmip experiments are shown in blue, and access-fw in red. Linear regression between percentage changes in each Bjerknes Feedback--BF1 (d), BF2 (e), and BF3 (f)--and the corresponding changes in Atlantic Niño variability across individual ensemble members of access-cmip and access-fw. Changes are computed for two periods (1985–2020 and 2080–2099) relative to the reference period. Shaded areas denote the 95% confidence intervals estimated via bootstrapping (10,000 iterations). Symbols differentiate ensemble simulations and periods, as indicated in the legend. R2 represents the average coefficient of determination across bootstrap samples, and the shaded area shows its standard deviation.Full size imageAnalysis of ACCESS-ESM1.5 future projections clarify the role of the AMOC in amplifying the weakening of the Atlantic Niño variability. In the access-cmip ensemble, the Atlantic Niño weakening is primarily driven by a weaker coupling between thermocline and SST anomalies in the eastern equatorial Atlantic1 (BF3: −30 ± 11%; Fig. 3c), as BF1 and BF2 do not show statistically significant changes (Fig. 3a, b). Considering future meltwater discharge (access-fw) leads to a significantly stronger response of BF3 (−60 ± 6%), but also leads to significant reductions in BF1 and BF2 (Fig. 3d,e). These results are in agreement with the mechanisms elucidated by the idealised AMOC weakening simulation (Fig. 2, Supplementary Fig. 7a,b). In access-fw, the winds in the western Atlantic (ATL4 region) weaken by 33% ± 2.4, while the wind response in access-cmip is significantly weaker (13 ± 2.9%; Supplementary Figs. 7c and 8a), which is consistent with a more intense atmospheric subtropical high in the North Atlantic Ocean under future projections with meltwater input (Supplementary Figs. 7 and 8). Additionally, as the thermocline feedback (BF2) measures the sensitivity of the thermocline slope to wind anomalies, weaker and more stable trade winds, along with the persistent propagation of downwelling Kelvin waves, contribute to a stronger BF2 weakening in access-fw (Fig. 3b).As the strength of the equatorial trades, which affects all three Bjerknes Feedbacks, is tied to the ITCZ position, it is important noting that the inclusion of greenhouse gases (GHG) forcing affects tropical precipitation differently. GHGs drive a rapid increase in precipitation in the deep tropics due to positive energy input at the equator under transient warming (e.g., 21st century)50, thus reducing the ITCZ shift caused by an AMOC weakening, while under prolonged CO2 warming (e.g., near-equilibrium climate) a delayed Southern Ocean warming is responsible for a stronger ITCZ shift51. This can potentially contribute to rather similar changes in the magnitude of the Atlantic Niño in access-cmip and access-fw at the end of the century (Supplementary Fig. 6), despite more pronounced weakened BFs in access-fw (Fig. 3a–c).To more precisely investigate the role of each feedback in Atlantic Niño weakening during the 21st century, we evaluate the relationship between the change in the strength of each feedback and the change in Atlantic Niño amplitude in access-cmip and access-fw ensembles. Results show that BF3 is the main feedback that controls the future response of the Atlantic Niño, explaining 51% of its reduced variability, followed by BF1 (15%) and BF2 (5%; Fig. 3d,e). The main feature that can affect the effectiveness of the BF3 is the thermocline depth in the eastern equatorial Atlantic, in which a deeper thermocline would reduce its influence on SST variability14. In addition, as shown in our results for the idealised AMOC weakening experiments, the AMOC affects the equatorial Atlantic thermocline depth through both atmospheric and oceanic teleconnections. Indeed, access-fw presents a more pronounced thermocline deepening that acces-cmip at the end of the 21st century (Fig. 4a). Therefore, we use our entire set of experiments, including idealized, historical, and future projections to evaluate the sensitivity of the upwelling feedback to the AMOC strength. We find that the intensity of BF3 is linearly related to the AMOC strength (Fig. 4b). During the mid-to-late 19th century, the AMOC is simulated to be at its strongest, consequently there is an intense coupling between surface and subsurface temperatures (represented by the BF3 index) in the eastern equatorial Atlantic. During the 20th century, both the AMOC and BF3 present a small but statistically significant weakening in access-fw. During the recent observational period, our historical simulations with meltwater can better capture the sensitivity of the BF3 to the AMOC weakening. The BF3 is, however, slightly overestimated by the ACCESS-ESM1.5 model, which may reflect the model’s stronger-than-observed internal variability. This trend continues across all simulations until the end of the century, with a larger reduction in future projections that include the effect of the Greenland ice sheet and Arctic glaciers melt. Ultimately, when the AMOC collapses, the BF3 vanishes (Fig. 4b). It is important to note that the equatorial thermocline deepening signal, due to an AMOC weakening, emerges due to the cumulative effect of the propagation of Kelvin waves. The time of emergence varies with the intensity of the AMOC weakening25. As such, in our access-fw simulations, the AMOC intensity completely diverges from access-cmip in the early 2020’s, while a clear thermocline response emerges in the mid-2030’s.Fig. 4: Role of the AMOC in modulating the upwelling feedback.a Time series of annual mean eastern equatorial thermocline for access-cmip (blue) and access-fw (red). b Relationship between the AMOC intensity and the upwelling feedback (BF3). Circles and squares represent simulations without and with freshwater forcing, respectively. X markers represent values derived from the idealised experiments. Observational data is denoted by the magenta diamond. Values represent the mean AMOC strength and BF3 strength averaged over each period indicated. r indicates the Pearson’s correlation coefficient, while p indicates its respective p-value. The observational estimate was excluded from the correlation analysis.Full size imageAs GHGs emissions directly warm the atmosphere and cause sea-ice and ice sheet melt, they drive an AMOC weakening through direct thermal forcing and indirectly through freshwater input. There is observational evidence that AMOC has been weakening since the mid-twentieth century26,27,45, and subpolar North Atlantic freshening could have played a major role in this weakening25. However, under intensified anthropogenic warming, the 21st-century AMOC weakening will likely be primarily driven by thermal forcing25,50,52,53. Nevertheless, the future contribution of meltwater is highly uncertain54. Our results suggest that a 50% AMOC weakening by 2100 (access-fw; Supplementary Fig. 5), in which approximately 70% is attributed to thermal forcing25, leads to a 60% reduction in the upwelling feedback. If considering the thermal forcing only (access-cmip), the AMOC slows down by 35%, while the upwelling feedback reduces by 33%.DiscussionOur results show that an AMOC weakening reduces the eastern equatorial Atlantic SST variability through two distinct but complementary mechanisms: (1) inducing an atmospheric teleconnection by intensifying the subtropical high-pressure system in the North Atlantic and leading to weaker equatorial trade winds, thus contributing to reduced zonal advection and upwelling feedbacks (Fig. 5); (2) triggering an oceanic teleconnection through the propagation of Kelvin waves from the subpolar Atlantic Ocean that, upon reaching the equatorial region, deepens the thermocline, thereby weakening the Atlantic Niño feedbacks, with major influence on the local upwelling feedback (Fig. 5). Taken together, both atmospheric and oceanic teleconnections described here contribute to a better understanding of the driving processes associated with thermocline-surface decoupling in the equatorial Atlantic.Fig. 5: Oceanic and atmospheric teleconnections from an AMOC decline to the equatorial Atlantic.Shading represents differences in sea surface temperature (top panel) and ocean temperature (bottom panel) between the end of the century (2080–2099) and the pre-industrial period (1850–1890) in the SSP5-8.5 experiments, including freshwater discharge (access-fw). Changes in deep-water formation in the subarctic Atlantic, driven by ocean heat uptake and ice sheet melt due to anthropogenic warming, trigger two teleconnection processes to the equatorial Atlantic: (1) intensified atmospheric circulation in the North Atlantic and southward ITCZ shift, in response to reduced northward oceanic heat transport, reduce the intensity of the equatorial trades, flattening the equatorial thermocline and weakening the Bjerknes Feedbacks; (2) displaced isopycnals in the subpolar North Atlantic trigger downwelling Kelvin waves that travel southward along the western boundary of the North Atlantic and cross the equator, promoting further deepening of the thermocline and contributing to the decoupling between oceanic and atmospheric processes.Full size imageThe AMOC is projected to decline under all global warming scenarios55. However, there are large uncertainties associated with projecting the changes in AMOC intensity throughout the twenty-first century56. These uncertainties stem from various factors, including different global warming scenarios55, systematic model biases, ice sheet melt25 and internal climate dynamics57,58. As such, the projected Atlantic Niño decline will likely be tied to the rate of the AMOC slow-down. The absence of interactive ice sheets in CMIP6 models likely underestimates the magnitude of the AMOC weakening25, thus possibly underestimating future Atlantic Niño decline. Finally, it is also important to understand the impact of changes in the South Atlantic Ocean on the equatorial Atlantic variability and what their combined impacts on precipitation will be.By accounting for subarctic meltwater in model simulations, we identify a potential weakening of 60 ± 6% in the eastern Atlantic upwelling feedback by the end of the century. A deepened thermocline and reduced upwelling variability in the eastern equatorial Atlantic can lead to weaker and less frequent ventilation of surface waters, impacting nutrient availability and thus tropical Atlantic fishery productivity. The shift of Atlantic Niño anomalies to the central Atlantic would reverse its impact on Eastern Africa coastal cities, while diminishing its influence on Amazon rainfall variability.MethodsEarth System modelIn this study, we use the Australian Community Climate and Earth System Simulator version 1.5 (ACCESS-ESM1.5)28, a fully coupled model comprising atmospheric, oceanic, land and sea ice sub-models. The atmospheric component is the UK Met Office Unified Model (UM) version 7.359 configured at 1.875∘ longitude by 1.25∘ latitude with 38 vertical levels, extending from the surface to 40 km. The land component, which includes biogeochemistry, is the CABLE model60 and is directly coupled to the atmospheric model. The oceanic component is the Modular Ocean Model version 5 (MOM5)61 from the Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory of the United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA-GFDL). The horizontal ocean grid has a nominal resolution of 1∘. The latitudinal resolution is higher at the equator (0.33∘) and in the Southern Ocean (0.4∘ at 70∘S). This component has 50 vertical levels, with 20 evenly spaced levels (10 metres in the first 200 metres of the water column). The sea ice component is the Los Alamos National Laboratory CICE model version 4.162, which runs on the same grid as the ocean model.Idealised meltwater experimentsACCESS-ESM1.5 is spun up under CMIP6 pre-industrial setup for 1,000 years31. From this state, a meltwater experiment is conducted by adding 0.4 Sv (1 Sv = 106 m3. s−1) of freshwater uniformly in the subpolar North Atlantic (50∘N to 70∘N) for 500 years. Although this forcing lacks realism, it’s valuable for studying climate impacts resulting from an AMOC collapse. Throughout the simulation, atmospheric CO2 concentration remains constant at the pre-industrial level (i.e., 284ppm), ensuring that any observed variations are solely due to the climatic effects of freshwater input. In this study, the control run under pre-industrial conditions is named AMOC-on, while the period at which AMOC stabilizes at around 3 Sv is referred to as AMOC-off.Historical and future projection experimentsWe use a 10-member ensemble of CMIP6 historical simulations from the ACCESS-ESM1.5 model63. These simulations incorporate observed climate forcings such as greenhouse gases, aerosols, and changes in land use. Additionally, we perform an extra 8-member ensemble of historical simulations with freshwater input in the subpolar North Atlantic (59∘N-72∘N and 65∘W-22∘W). This region is smaller than the one used in ‘idealized’ experiments and focuses on meltwater and solid ice runoff from Greenland and Arctic glaciers. The freshwater input experimental design is based on the evolution of observation-based SST and salinity AMOC indices25,45,64, Greenland warming, sea-ice retreat and changes in Greenland surface mass balance (Supplementary Fig. 5). Meltwater forcing in these historical simulations begins in 1960 with a constant input of 0.05 Sv until 1989, corresponding to a rapid sea-ice retreat and Greenland warming trend65. From 1990 to 1999, observational data suggest a nearly constant sea-ice extent and no significant changes in Greenland surface mass balance. As such, no freshwater forcing is applied during this period. From 2000, observations indicate substantial Greenland warming and ice loss and a nearly 30% sea-ice retreat. 0.05 Sv freshwater input is thus applied between 2000 and 2004, increasing to 0.075 Sv from 2005 to 2014, which marks the end of the CMIP6 historical protocol. We note that our freshwater estimates (0 to 75 mSv) to the subarctic Atlantic are in agreement with observational estimates (5 to 63 mSv)49,66 over the same period; however, most of our fluxes (50 to 75 mSv) lie on the upper-end of observational estimates. Nonetheless, the historical simulations with freshwater can better capture the observed AMOC weakening trend since 195725 (Supplementary Fig. 5). To evaluate the projected impact of freshwater forcing, we use the high-emissions scenario (ssp585)67. This scenario simulates a continuous Greenland warming throughout the 21st century, but no meltwater flux or ice discharge due to the melting of the Greenland ice-sheet or Arctic glaciers is included. To evaluate a more realistic scenario, we consider a ssp585 experiment with a linear increase in freshwater input in the subpolar Atlantic. This is implemented through decadal increments of 0.025 Sv starting from 0.1 Sv in 2020. From 2014 to 2019, a freshwater input of 0.075 Sv is kept, corresponding to the forcing at the end of the historical simulations. The combined historical and ssp585 experiments with freshwater input are referred in the main text as access-fw, while standard CMIP6 ACCESS-ESM1.5 simulations of the same scenarios are referred as access-cmip. A full description and justification of historical and future projections experiments with freshwater input can be found in ref. 25.AMOC strengthComputed as the annual maximum stream function (Sv) at 26∘N in the North Atlantic OceanVariability of Atlantic NiñoMeasured by the standard deviation of the SSTa during June, July and August in the eastern equatorial Atlantic (ATL3; 3∘S-3∘N, 20∘W-0∘).ITCZ indexComputed as the precipitation weighted mean latitude using values greater than 50% of the precipitation maximum in the zonal mean over oceanic regions only33.Dynamical ocean-atmosphere feedbacksWe calculate the three primary components of Bjerknes Feedbacks (BF) involving SST, thermocline depth, and zonal surface winds to investigate the potential dynamical drivers of changes in the Atlantic Niño variability. The three components are determined using linear regression between the associated variables14,68. Three main feedbacks are given by: (1) zonal advection feedback: regression of eastern equatorial Atlantic (ATL3;3∘S-3∘N, 20∘W-0∘) SST anomalies in June, July and August (JJA) onto western equatorial Atlantic (ATL4;3∘S-3∘N, 40∘W-20∘W) zonal wind stress anomalies. (2) thermocline feedback: regression of equatorial thermocline slope (difference between the mean Z20 in ATL3 and ATL4) anomalies during JJA onto zonal wind stress anomalies over the ATL4 region during March, April and May (MAM). (3) upwelling feedback: regression of SSTa in ATL3 onto thermocline depth (depth of the 20∘C isotherm) anomalies in ATL3 in JJA.Thermal wind balanceThe Thermal wind equations relate the vertical velocity shear to horizontal density gradients. These equations can be derived from the horizontal geostrophic components. Assuming a small Rossby number, thin aspect ratio, Boussinesq approximation, Euler Equation and f-plane the Navier-Stokes equation becomes:$$-fu=\frac{1}{\rho }\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}$$
                    (1)
                $$fv=\frac{1}{\rho }\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}$$
                    (2)
                Where p(x, y, z) is the pressure, u(x, y, z) and v(x, y, z) are the zonal and meridional velocities respectively, ρ(x, y, z) is the seawater density and f in the Coriolis parameter on the f-plane. Taking the vertical derivative of equations (1) and (2), and estimating density from the hydrostatic balance, the geostrophic velocity shear is given by the thermal-wind balance:$$\frac{\partial v}{\partial z}=-\frac{g}{{\rho }_{0}f}\frac{\partial \rho }{\partial x}$$
                    (3)
                $$\frac{\partial u}{\partial z}=\frac{g}{{\rho }_{0}f}\frac{\partial \rho }{\partial y}$$
                    (4)
                where ρ0 is the reference density and g the gravitational acceleration. This relationship indicates that higher velocities occur in regions of intense horizontal density gradients. The propagation of Kelvin waves effectively modifies density gradients along the boundary (Supplementary Fig. 4a, c), thus affecting the velocities of boundary currents baroclinically (Supplementary Fig. 4b, d). In this analysis, the offshore vertical density gradient was removed in order to isolate the effect of the propagation of coastally trapped waves. Lastly, it is important to note that the amplitude of the Kelvin waves triggered by freshwater anomalies is dependent on the intensity of the anomaly at the western boundary. Sensitivity experiments indicate that the smaller freshwater input region (59-72∘N and 65∘W-22∘W), used in access-fw simulations, generates stronger density anomalies close to the western boundary and thus triggers Kelvin waves of higher amplitude than the ones generated by the broader input region used in the idealized experiment (50∘N-70∘N and 70∘W-0∘E). Noting that the majority of the observed meltwater input occurs in Baffin Bay and Davis Strait (at the western boundary)49, it is possible that while the idealized experiment underestimates the amplitude of the Kelvin waves, these are overestimated in access-fw simulations.

Data availability
              
              Observational SST data were downloaded from the United Kingdom Met Office repository (https://www.metoffice.gov.uk/hadobs/hadisst/). Gridded thermocline depth (depth of 20∘C isotherm) is available from the Ocean Reanalysis System Version 5 (ORA-S5) public repository (https://www.ecmwf.int/en/research/climate-reanalysis/ocean-reanalysis). AMOC estimates from the RAPID-array are available at https://rapid.ac.uk/. Satellite-based AMOC estimates can be obtained through direct contact with Dr.Eleonor Frajka-Williams (eleanor.frajka@uni-hamburg.de). ACCESS-ESM1.5 simulations performed under the CMIP6 project (piControl, historical and ssp585) are publicly available through the Earth System Grid Federation online repository.
            Code availability
              
              Computational code for the ACCESS-ESM1.5 model is available at the ARC CoE for Climate Extremes Computational Modelling Systems (https://github.com/coecms/access-esm). Computational codes for the data analyses performed in this study are available upon request from the corresponding author.
